newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, May 12.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, May 12.

text.p: The following are the highlights of stories from the Irish press on Monday.

- The Progressive Democrats sought clarification from Fianna Fail on Sunday that a ceasefire would have to be in place before a future coalition government involving the parties would meet Sinn Fein or loyalist leaders.
- The Irish National Liberation Army is likely to mount further attacks in Northern Ireland after the murder of off-duty RUC officer Darren Bradshaw.
- The board of Avonmore Foods holds a crucial meeting on Monday to discuss its offer for Waterford Foods.
- The three Irish government parties will start the general election campaign later this week with a package of 21 pledges, the cornerstone of their joint bid to retain power.
- A plan to individually assess every person claiming social security assistance will be unveiled by the Irish government on Tuesday.

- The Irish government has committed itself to establishing a partnership with Britain in relation to employment training, which would involve mutual recognition of courses and joint participation by trainees on both islands.
- Avonmore Foods' Co-op and plc boards meet on Monday to review the merger proposals stymied since their rejection by Waterford Foods ten days ago.
- Nelson Mandela has made a dramatic intervention in the Northern Ireland peace process and will act as mediator at a special summit in South Africa later this month.

- Irish Prime Minister, John Bruton, faced with another poor opinion poll which forecasts a narrow defeat for the Irish government at the hands of Fianna Fail and the Progressive Democrats, on Sunday all but called the general election for June 6.
